author: 237dmitry
body:
## Summary of the new feature/enhancement
PowerShell's `[SG]et-Clipboard` functional independence.

How to work with the clipboard in Linux using PowerShell? If the cmdlet `Get-Clipboard` requires installing `xclip` (gcb is a stub?), then what about `Set-Clipboard`? You can certainly use native utilities, but why then useless cmdlets?

#### My Environment
OS: KDE neon User Edition 5.20 x64
PowerShell v7.1.2 (manual install: download, unpack, symlink to /usr/bin)
xclip v0.13-1

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
`xclip` is used by _both_ commands, as it supports both copying to and retrieving from the clipboard.

The problem with Linux platforms is that they can have a variety of GUI shells (if any), so there's no single utility or API that provides clipboard access on all of them.

The X11-based [`xclip` utility](https://github.com/astrand/xclip) works on all GUI shells (desktops) that are [X11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X_Window_System)-based, such as on Ubuntu, a popular Linux distro.

While `xclip` may not be _preinstalled_, PowerShell does take advantage of it _if present_.

> but why then useless cmdlets?

As a _multi-platform_ shell, PowerShell aims to provide commands that work the same on _all_ supported platforms.

With `xclip` present on a Linux distro, that aim is met (with respect to _text_ - see #14758).

In its absence, the aim is met to a _limited_ degree, via a _PowerShell-specific_ clipboard scoped to the _current session_. That is, you can _pair_ `Set-Clipboard`  and `Get-Clipboard` calls - and `Get-Clipboard` then only sees content copied by `Set-Clipboard`, not by other commands - though you won't have access to the platform's true, cross-process clipboard.

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body:
Good point - I also see the problem in 7.1.2 and 7.2.0-preview.3, on Ubuntu 18.04, and this is clearly a bug.

The problem must be related to how PowerShell waits for `xclip` to exit.

Please update your original post with the details of your environment, as requested in the issue template (edit: I now see that you used the "Feature Request/Idea" rather than the "Bug" template - only the latter requests this information, but since this actually a _bug_, it should be added), and please change the issue title to reflect that `Set-Clipboard` on Linux with `xclip` present  _hangs_.

The workaround for now is to use `xclip` explicitly; e.g., `'foo' | xclip -selection clipboard`
